Macculloch belong to the same series of rocks & agree
with Gneiss or Mica Schist in every thing but mineral
composition.: <s>for the sake of brevity therefore I shall only
use those two names to include all varieties of foliated
Rocks, As<\s> 
The difference of their <s>mineral ingredients<\s> constituent parts
appears to have produced no alteration in the foliation
of these rocks, which follows the same laws in them all <s>these rocks<\s>; the only
variat<s>y<\s>ion in that respect consists<s>ing<\s> in the greater or less completeness
of the separation of the different minerals <s>constituents<\s> into
parallel layers; and these are but different stages of
one process. For the sake of brevity, therefore I shall use the terms Gneiss and Mica Schist to include
all the varieties of foliated rocks.
Under the <s>common<\s> name of <u>Quartz Rock<\u> Macculloch has
classed in connection with Gneiss & the various Schists
two sets of rocks belonging geologically to two most distinct classes
and only resembling each other mineralogically:
<s>this has given rise to  great confusion in his writings
& in those of many subsequent authors; & has not only been a
great obstacle to the true classification of the rocks
of Scotland, but has probably tended more than
any other cause to produce the prevailing erroneous notions
on the subject of metamorphic rocks to which
I shall return farther on.<\s>
The quartz rocks of Glenorchy and Tyndrum* with
<s>several<\s> most of the varieties composed of Quartz & Felspar, or Quartz & Mica, enumerated in Macculloch’s classi
fication of rocks, belong to Gneiss, <s>from with<\s> from which they
<s>are [text?] usually found<\s> differ<s>ing<\s> only in simplicity of composition:
and with which they are usually found:
these are foliated rocks, & are here regarded as so
